thread.title: Drivers should prepare for weekend traffic headaches
thread.title_full: Drivers should prepare for weekend traffic headaches | www.kirotv.com

author: kirotv.com
title: Drivers should prepare for weekend traffic headaches
text:
Drivers should be prepared for weekend traffic headaches as crews will be back inside the I-90 tunnels near Lake Washington. But it’s not the only closure this weekend.
It will be the sixth of 30 weekend closures to prepare for the $3.6 billion Eastlink Light Rail, which will occupy the express lanes over Lake Washington.
“This is the sort of thing we need to get done now to get ready for laying rails on the bridge,” said Bruce Gray with Sound Transit.
The eastbound lanes are being squeezed to one lane and diverted onto the express lanes from Friday at 11 p.m. to Monday at 5 a.m.
In addition, the Montlake Bridge will close Saturday at 5 a.m. and reopen Sunday at 5 p.m. for bridge deck repair.
In Bothell, drivers won't be able to connect on I-405 to SR 522 from 10 p.m. Friday until noon Sunday.
The Washington Department of Transportation says to plan ahead.
Some major closures coming up this weekend. All the details here: https://t.co/h9pwPIaDe9
— Alexis Smith (@AlexisKIRO7) October 22, 2015 “(You) still can get there, you just don't want to get in your car like it’s any normal day and get on the road,” said WSDOT spokesman Travis Phelps.
And there’s a tip for those who are looking to avoid I-5 and use light rail.
“Some things folks don't know, those two-hour parking restrictions around the Rainier Valley are not in effect on the weekends, so it's a good option to park and walk to the train,” said Gray.
On Sunday, the Sounders have a 4 p.m. game so tens of thousands of fans will be heading into Seattle.
Sound Transit will run extra trains from the north and the south. They recommend that drivers come to the game from the south and use side streets -- anything but I-5.
Looking ahead, the Alaskan Way Viaduct will be closed Halloween weekend for an inspection.
For more information, see the WSDOT blog.
